Can you give an example of what sorts of tsan failures could be hidden by this?

It seems like the main benefit of this over #17367 is that the latter requires callers to use the new API in cases where tsan can't figure things out on its own.  While it does seem better for the call combiner to figure this out on its own instead of making callers deal with it, I am willing to deal with the extra API complexity, as long as it's not too intrusive, especially if it avoids masking real problems.  Is it correct to assume that the set of cases where the new API would need to be used should be fairly rare?

Thank you Mark for the review! I agree, it's much nicer if we can pull it off transparently.

I gave this another shot. Please see the new commit that I just pushed. The idea is to create a fake lock that lives as long as needed for TSAN annotations. I can confirm it works perfectly and transparently. PTAL. thanks!

Please note that below is my reply on the previous version and doesn't apply to the most recent version:

> Can you give an example of what sorts of tsan failures could be hidden by this?
Sure. First problem is that the pointer that I annotated in previous version is accessed when it's freed. So, we are not really marking the correct memory region (i.e., the memory region can be reused before our annotation).

Second, I had to mark as:
AFTER -> do work -> BEFORE 

So that when we return from the original closure up to the next call to the `tsan_closure` we are marking everything as ordered by the `call_combiner`'s `size` field. If this can be used by tsan to prove synchronized access, I believe we can have false negatives.
